bug.author: joklaff
bug.description:
Describe the bug I am trying to continue the training of the news-forward language model on domain specific data, which works in a jupyter notebook but fails when executing the code in a plain python script. The error message is the following: <denchmark-code>Traceback (most recent call last): File "flair-fine-tuning.py", line 35, in <module> checkpoint=True) File "/home/jonas/.pyenv/versions/3.7.2/lib/python3.7/site-packages/flair/trainers/language_model_trainer.py", line 358, in train loss = self.loss_function(output.view(-1, ntokens), targets) RuntimeError: shape '[-1, 275]' is invalid for input of size 630000 </denchmark-code>
I prepared the corpus as stated in <denchmark-link:https://github.com/zalandoresearch/flair/blob/master/resources/docs/TUTORIAL_9_TRAINING_LM_EMBEDDINGS.md>part 9 of the tutorial</denchmark-link> . The notebook server runs from the main directory and both the notebook as well as the script are in the same level: <denchmark-code>corpus - test.txt - train -- train_split_* - valid.txt jupyter_notebook_train.ipynb plain_python_train.py </denchmark-code>
When I run the following code in the jupyter notebook the training runs as expected but if I try to run it in a plain python script I get the abovementioned error. To Reproduce To reproduce the error try to run the following script with: python 3.7.2 flair==0.4.2 torch==1.1.0 Executed code: <denchmark-code>from flair.data import Dictionary from flair.embeddings import FlairEmbeddings from flair.trainers.language_model_trainer import LanguageModelTrainer, TextCorpus from pathlib import Path
# are you training a forward or backward LM? is_forward_lm = True
# load the default character dictionary dictionary: Dictionary = Dictionary.load('chars')
# get your corpus, process forward and at the character level corpus = TextCorpus(Path('./corpus'), dictionary, is_forward_lm, character_level=True)
# instantiate an existing LM, such as one from the FlairEmbeddings language_model = FlairEmbeddings('news-forward').lm
# use the model trainer to fine-tune this model on your corpus trainer = LanguageModelTrainer(language_model, corpus)
trainer.train(Path('resources/taggers/language_model'), sequence_length=100, mini_batch_size=100, max_epochs=50, learning_rate=20, anneal_factor=0.4, patience=10, checkpoint=True)
</denchmark-code>
Environment (please complete the following information): Local Machine:
OS [e.g. iOS, Linux]: Manjaro Linux 18.0.4 Illyria Version [e.g. flair-0.3.2]: python 3.7.2 flair==0.4.2 torch==1.1.0
Additional Machine:
OS: Ubuntu 18.04.1 LTS (GNU/Linux 4.15.0-43-generic x86_64) Versions: python 3.7.2 flair==0.4.2 torch==1.1.0
Additional context I hope I included all the necessary information and really much looking forward to any advice to solve this problem since I srsly have no clue what happened. I also tested the behavior on the above stated additional machine and the message is exactly the same. If i missed any information please let me know....I think i probably just make a silly mistake but haven't spotted it so far... Thanks so many in advance!

comments.comment:
Hi <denchmark-link:https://github.com/joklaff>@joklaff</denchmark-link> thanks for sharing the code snippet - I think the problem is that there is a mismatch in the character dictionary between the model you load and the model you train. I.e. the model you load in the line language_model = FlairEmbeddings('news-forward').lm may have been trained with a different Dictionary than the one you get with dictionary: Dictionary = Dictionary.load('chars') To fix this, you could make sure to use the same dictionary of the existing language model. You would need to change your code like this: from flair.data import Dictionary from flair.embeddings import FlairEmbeddings from flair.trainers.language_model_trainer import LanguageModelTrainer, TextCorpus
# are you training a forward or backward LM? is_forward_lm = True
# instantiate an existing LM, such as one from the FlairEmbeddings language_model = FlairEmbeddings('news-forward').lm
# get the dictionary from the existing language model dictionary: Dictionary = language_model.dictionary
# get your corpus, process forward and at the character level corpus = TextCorpus('./corpus', dictionary, is_forward_lm, character_level=True)
# use the model trainer to fine-tune this model on your corpus trainer = LanguageModelTrainer(language_model, corpus)
trainer.train('resources/taggers/language_model', sequence_length=100, mini_batch_size=100, max_epochs=50, learning_rate=20, anneal_factor=0.4, patience=10, checkpoint=True) I'll correct this in the tutorial as well!
Closing for now, please feel free to reopen if there are any more questions!
Thank you very much for the super quick reply! Your solution solved the problem for me üëç
